The heterogeneous ethanol carbonylation of Ni supported on activated carbon (Ni/AC) is typically associated with significant activity loss, largely due to the facile occurrence of carbon deposition and Ni loss. In this study, the chlorine-containing Ni/AC catalysts were synthesized via the incipient wetness method and exhibited superior stability compared to catalysts without chlorine. Correlation of the catalytic performance and catalyst structure revealed that chlorine addition to Ni/AC reduced the amount of carbon deposition. Moreover, it is evident that there is a robust interaction between chlorine and Ni, as evidenced by XPS and H2-TPR, which can significantly impede the Ni loss during the reaction. The results of in-situ DRIFTS and CO-TPD experiments demonstrate that the addition of chlorine impedes the adsorption of iodine species on Ni/AC catalysts, which consequently affects the adsorption capacity of CO closely associated with the product selectivity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethanol carbonylation Stability Ni loss Carbon deposition Chlorine Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The oxo-synthesis of acids and esters from alcohols has received wide attention in the chemical industry. The homogeneous catalytic methanol carbonylation to acetic acid has been industrialized [1,2]. Currently, heterogeneous catalytic methanol carbonylation is more attractive and has been extensively researched as an alternative to the industrial synthesis of acetic acid due to its advantages, including easy separating of products, low reaction pressure and a relatively low corrosion degree [2,3]. As the important oxygenate chemical intermediates, propionic acid (PA) is employed in the anticorrosion of food and feed, the synthesis of pharmaceuticals and pesticides, and its demand is increasing [4,5]. Ethyl propionate (EP), a derivative of propionic acid, is also used as a solvent and additive [5]. Besides, as reaction feed stock, ethanol could be easily obtained from biomass and coal-ethanol technology [6-8]. Therefore, the preparation of PA and EP from heterogeneous ethanol carbonylation is of great practical significance for the development of non-petroleum-based route [9-13]. Ni-based heterogeneous catalysts supported by activated carbon (AC) have been explored in ethanol and methanol carbonylation for many years due to low cost and good activity [12,14]. However, the deactivation issues of Ni-based catalysts impede practical application of this process in larger scales. Significant carbon deposition is often observed on catalysts after alcohol carbonylation reactions, particularly on Ni/AC catalysts, as well as on precious metal catalysts like Ir/AC catalyst [15-17]. The analysis of the post-reaction catalyst indicates that carbon deposition is caused by the adsorption of carbonylation products and intermediates in micropore of catalysts (such as PA, EP and intermediates containing iodine) [12,17]. This results in the blockage of micropores and an increase in the diffusion limitations over time [18-20]. Generally, the catalyst after the reaction can be treated with hydrogen to remove the carbon deposited [16,21,22]. However, the regenerated catalyst deactivates faster than the original catalyst [15]. Pang et al. [20] prepared catalysts with varying amounts of oxygen-containing groups and observed that a high oxygen content can enhance the stability of Ni/AC catalysts via impeding carbon deposition. Aggregation of the Ni particles was also observed on the catalyst after the reaction [15,23]. Zhang et al. [24] demonstrated that the incorporation of CeO₂ can enhance Ni dispersion and inhibit Ni particles sintering in Ni/AC catalysts, thereby enhancing the catalyst's stability. Although the aforementioned observations, it has been indicated that the dimensions of Ni particles exert a minimal effect on the carbonylation activity of the catalyst [17,25,26]. Furthermore, the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) analysis indicated a decrease in the Ni content of the catalyst after the reaction [12,15,17]. Gao et al. [12] synthesized a Ni-Cu alloy catalysts modified with nitrogen and oxygen groups to enhance the interaction between Ni-Cu metal and AC. The synergistic effect of alloys and oxygen and nitrogen group modification has been demonstrated to inhibit Ni loss and to enhance the stability of the catalyst. Generally, the deactivation in ethanol carbonylation of Ni/AC catalysts is primarily attributed to carbon disposition and Ni loss. Strengthening the interaction between the active metal site and support can prevent the accumulation and loss of active components, thereby enhancing catalyst stability [27,28]. Nevertheless, the carbonylation reaction necessitates electron transfer between AC and Ni in order to guarantee optimal catalytic efficacy [29]. Thus, enhancing the interaction between the metal and AC can significantly reduce the carbonylation reaction activity of Ni/AC catalysts but improve the catalyst stability. Li et al. [30] prepared an atomically dispersed NiN4Cl active site on nickel-nitrogen-carbon catalyst for CO2 electroreduction. The results indicate that NiN4Cl sites on a Cl-doped support serve to inhibit Ni leaching and thereby enhance stability. Based on the analysis above, the synthesis of the chlorine-containing Ni/AC catalysts was achieved through the incipient wetness method to improve the catalytic stability. The catalytic structure and performance were correlated by series characterizations. The addition of chlorine effectively inhibits carbon deposition and Ni loss, thereby enhancing the catalytic stability. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O (99.9%), HNO3 (65.0-68.0%) and HCl (36.0-38.0%) were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. AC support (20-40 mesh) was provided by Norit Co. Ltd in the Netherlands. Deionized water (WP-UP-YZ-60, Sichuan woerte technology Co., Ltd.) was used in the experiment. 2.2 Preparation of Ni/AC catalysts The Ni/AC catalysts were synthesized via the conventional incipient wetness impregnation method. 2.36 g Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O was dissolved in 6.0 mL deionized water. Then 5.00 g of AC support was impregnated in the above-mentioned solution. After drying in an oven at 120 °C overnight, the sample was subjected to calcination under nitrogen atmosphere at 450 °C for a period of 3 h, resulting in the decomposition of nickel acetate into nickel oxide and the production of a fresh catalyst. The catalyst is referred as Ni/AC-H2O. To prepare the chlorine-containing catalysts, 2.0 and 6.0 mL of HCl were add to the deionized water, leaving the total volume of the solution unchanged. The samples are designated as Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl, respectively. In order to eliminate the influence of pH, 1.1 mL of HNO3 was incorporated into the deionized water, thus establishing a pH value for the solution that was identical to that of Ni/AC-2HCl. The catalyst is designated as Ni/AC-HNO3. 2.3 Catalyst characterization To obtain the textural properties of catalysts, the N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were obtained with an ASAP2020 analyzer. Scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive spectrometer (SEM-EDS) images of the catalyst were also recorded on a HITACHI SU8020 Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM). To obtain the amount of carbon deposition, Thermogravimetric-differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC) characterization was performed via a NETZSCH STA 449F3 analyzer under O2 atmosphere. To obtain the phase structure of catalysts, X-ray diffraction analysis (XRD) was carried out via a Smartlab-SE multifunctional diffractometer. To obtain the Ni content of the catalysts, inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) measurements were performed by an Agilent 725-ES instrument (USA). Before the measurement, the 25 mg catalyst was treated at 750 °C in air for 3 h, then the remaining residue was dissolved completely with nitric acid. In order to acquire the valence state of Ni, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conductive via a Thermon ESCALAB 250 xi spectrometer. The structure of catalysts was analyzed using a LabRAM HR micro confocal Raman spectrometer equipped with a 532 nm laser. In order to ascertain the reducibility of the catalyst, a hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) test was conducted. To ascertain the CO adsorption capacity of the catalyst, a CO temperature-programmed desorption (CO-TPD) test was performed. H2-TPR and CO-TPD of the samples were performed on the ChemBET Pulsar TPR/TPD analyzer. The samples (200 mg) were treated with a three-step procedure to obtain H2-TPR data: 300 °C in He flow for 1 h, then 40 °C in H2/Ar flow for 40 min and finally rise to 550 °C in H2/Ar flow (30 mL·min-1). The fresh catalyst samples (100 mg) were subjected to the following procedure to obtain CO-TPD data: 400 °C in H2/Ar flow for 1 h, then room temperature in He flow and CO flow for 1 h each, finally in He flow for 30 min and in He flow (20 mL·min-1) heated to 200 °C (15 °C·min-1). The catalyst samples after reaction were firstly pretreated at 200 °C in He flow instead of H2/Ar flow. To elucidate the characteristics of surface species, in-situ diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was carried out via a BRUKER Vetex70 instrument. The fresh catalyst samples (10 mg) were subjected to the following procedure: 400 °C in H2 flow for 1 h, then 30 °C in N2 flow for 30 min, finally 220 °C in EtOH + CO flow and EtOH + EtI + CO flow for different reaction times. And a series of DRIFTS spectra were collected at a timely moment. 2.4 Catalyst evaluation The heterogeneous ethanol (EtOH) carbonylation reaction was evaluated in a fixed-bed reactor. 2.0 g catalyst was positioned at the center of the quartz tube (Φ 12 mm * 300 mm, Scheme 1 ). Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced at 400 °C for 3 h in a mixed atmosphere of H2/N2 (vol/vol = 1/4, 40 mL·min-1), and then lowered to the reaction temperature. The mixed solution of EtOH and ethyl iodide (EtI) (EtOH:EtI (molar ratio) = 10:1) was then pumped into the gasifier by microinjection pump at 0.5 L·(kgcat·h)-1 for gasification, accompanied by switching CO (40 mL·min-1) into the reactor. The main products are PA and EP with ethylene and trace amounts of diethyl ether and ethane as the by-products, in addition to the unreacted EtOH, CO and EtI. The products were analyzed offline using a gas chromatography (Agilent 7890A) equipped with TCD (chromatographic column: Porapak-Q). The selectivity, yield and space time yield (STY) of EP and PA, EtOH and EtI conversion are calculated as follows: Conv . EtOH = n EtOH , in − n EtOH , out n EtOH , in × 100 % Conv . EtI = n EtI , in − n EtI , out n EtI , in × 100 % Sel . ( PA + EP ) = 2 n PA + n EP ( n EtOH , in − n EtOH , out ) + ( n EtI , in − n EtI , out ) × 100 % Yield of ( PA + EP ) = ( Conv . EtOH × 10 + Conv . EtI × 1 ) 11 × Sel . ( PA + EP ) × 100 % STY of ( PA + EP ) = n PA + n EP m cat . × t mcat. is the mass of catalyst (g); t represents the reaction time of the catalyst (h). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The performances of Ni/AC catalysts for heterogeneous ethanol carbonylation different are compared in Fig. 1 and Table 1 . The activity of ethanol carbonylation was described by the STY of PA and EP. It is evident that the STY and yield of PA and EP for all catalysts reached its maximum value at 4 h. The STY of PA and EP for Ni/AC-H2O and Ni/AC-2HCl at 4 h is similar (2.39 vs 2.34 mmol·(gcat·h)-1, which is comparable to that (2.20 mmol·(mLcat·h)-1 reported by Hu et al. for homogeneous Rh-based catalysts [9]. Moreover, the yields of PA and EP for Ni/AC-H2O and Ni/AC-2HCl at 8 h were comparable to that (38.5%) reported by Gao et al. for Cu-Ni/NOAC catalyst [12]. Comparatively, Ni/AC-2HCl exhibits similar activity than Ni/AC-H2O. However, Ni/AC-6HCl shows significant decline in activity compared with Ni/AC-H2O. Consequently, by comparison with Ni/AC-H2O, the activity of ethanol carbonylation seems to maintained on Ni/AC catalyst after the introduction of small amount of chlorine, while shows great decline for the catalysts prepared by adding overabundant chlorine. As for the catalytic stability, however, EtOH conversion increased rapidly during the initial 6 h then gradually decreased, accompanied by PA and EP selectivity gradually decreasing with the prolonging reaction time for all catalyst samples. As reported by Gao et al. [12], the yield of the Cu-Ni/NOAC catalyst decreased by 53.7% after 50 h of reaction, accompanied by a notable decrease in activity. In order to facilitate a more precise comparison of the catalytic stability, it is necessary to set the highest activity (at 4 h) for each catalyst as 100%. Following a reaction time of 30 hours, the deactivation of Ni/AC-H₂O reached a maximum of 63.2%. It is noteworthy that at the same pH of the impregnation solution, the activity loss of Ni/AC-2HCl is 45.7%, which is significantly lower than that observed for Ni/AC-HNO3 (58.8%). As the adding amount of HCl increased, the activity loss of Ni/AC-6HCl is observed to be only 28.8%. And the selectivity of PA and EP in Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl at 30 h was 37.1% and 37.4%, respectively, which was significantly higher than the 30.0% of Ni/AC-H2O. According to the results of catalytic performance, it appears that the chlorine adding may have a positive impact on catalyst stability. 3.2 Textural properties of the catalysts To ascertain the role of chlorine on catalytic stability and activity in ethanol carbonylation, a series of characterizations were performed to explore the structure and properties of the catalysts. The pore size has a crucial effect on ethanol carbonylation of Ni/AC catalysts, such as the adsorption of reactants and products [17,19,31]. Fig. 2 illustrates the N2 adsorption-desorption results of AC and Ni/AC catalysts. According to IUPAC and QSDFT model, AC support exhibit type I(a) isotherms and presents the narrow micropore size distribution with a 0.59 nm optimum pore size [32]. For the Ni-loaded catalysts, no significant changes in N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms or pore structure were observed. After Ni loading, the values of SBET and Vtotal of all catalysts exhibited a reduction in comparison to the AC support, as detailed in Table 2 . The ratio of Vmicro/Vtotal for all catalysts slightly increased, possibly due to the blocking of some pore in AC support after impregnating active metal [33,34]. After the reaction, the micropore located at 0.59 nm was observed to disappear for all catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 2d. the values of SBET and Vtotal continued to decrease for all catalysts after the reaction, as presented in Table 2. The results show that SBET of Ni/AC-H2O after reaction decreased by 54.2%, while that of Ni/AC-6HCl after reaction exhibited the lowest drop at 35.6%. The reduction in specific surface area for Ni/AC-HNO3 was similar to Ni/AC-2HCl, 42.8% and 44.5%, respectively. This phenomenon may be assigned to the carbon deposition and the adsorption of iodinated species in the micropores of the catalysts [17,20,21]. 3.3 The carbon deposition of the catalysts Raman spectra was carried out to detect the carbon deposition of Ni/AC catalysts, as displayed in Fig. 3 . Obviously, the signal intensity of post-reaction catalysts increased, suggesting the carbon disposition occurred on the catalysts after reaction. The ratio of I(D)/I(G) is marginally higher on the catalyst after reaction than that of the corresponding fresh catalysts, indicating that the amorphous carbon is deposited on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the increase in the ratio of I(D)/I(G) for chlorine-containing catalysts is slightly lower than that of Ni/AC-H2O and Ni/AC-HNO3. This is probably because the carbon deposition predominantly occupied the micropores of the catalysts according to the results of N2 physisorption isotherms. In order to accurately detect the content of carbon deposition, Ni/AC catalyst was further analyzed by TG-DSC, as illustrated in Fig. 4 . All of the fresh catalysts exhibit a single weight loss at 400-650 °C and are accompanied by a noticeable exothermic reaction. This is due to the decomposition of the AC support in the air. However, in addition to the pronounced peak observed at temperatures between 400 and 650°C, TG-DSC curve of post-reaction catalysts displays the minor peak of weight loss between 150 and 400°C, accompanied by an exothermic peak. This phenomenon is ascribed to the combustion of the deposited carbon, as evidenced by the considerable release of CO and CO2 within this temperature range [17]. The percentages of deposited carbon species for Ni/AC-H2O, Ni/AC-HNO3, Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl are 28.2%, 30.6%, 24.6% and 24.9%, respectively. Consequently, the chlorine-containing catalysts exhibit less carbon deposition and thus activity loss compared to Ni/AC-H2O and Ni/AC-HNO3. These observations demonstrate that the chlorine is essential part of in inhibiting the carbon deposition. However, possessing similar content of deposited carbon species, Ni/AC-6HCl exhibited better catalytic stability than Ni/AC-2HCl, which implies that there is still other reason for the improved catalyst stability besides that chlorine partially prevents the carbon deposition of the Ni/AC catalysts in the ethanol carbonylation reaction. 3.4 XRD analysis Fig. 5 demonstrates the XRD patterns of Ni/AC catalysts at different stages. The fresh Ni/AC catalysts exhibit a typical carbon peak at 2θ = 23.0° and obvious NiO peaks at 2θ = 37.2°, 43.2°, 62.9° and 75.4°, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) crystal planes, respectively. The faint Ni peaks are observed at 2θ = 44.5° and 51.8° for all the catalysts except Ni/AC-HNO3. These results suggest that a small amount of NiO species may have been reduced by AC support during the calcination process [24]. In fresh chlorine-containing catalysts, the characteristic peaks of NiCl2 were observed at 2θ = 15.3°, 30.2°, 36.4° and 52.8°, corresponding to the (003), (101), (104) and (110) crystal planes, respectively. Moreover, the peak intensities of NiCl2 decreased while the peak intensities of NiO increased for Ni/AC-6HCl compared with Ni/AC-2HCl. After reduction, as presented in Fig. 5b, only the Ni0 peaks are located at 2θ = 44.5°, 51.8° and 76.3°, which belong to the (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes, respectively. This clearly demonstrated that NiO and NiCl2 species could be reduced completely to metallic Ni0 under the experimental condition. The Ni crystallite sizes were calculated via the Scherrer equation to be 15 nm, 16 nm, 22 nm and 36 nm for Ni/AC-H2O, Ni/AC-HNO3, Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl, respectively. Fig. 5c reveals that the peaks of Ni species disappear in Ni/AC-H2O after the reaction for 30 h. Moreover, for other three catalysts, the peaks of NiI2 are observed at 2θ = 13.4°, 27.2°, 32.1° and 46.5°, corresponding to (003), (012), (100) and (100) crystal planes, respectively. Additionally, the peaks of NiI2·6H2O in Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl are observed at 2θ = 22.6°, 23.3°, 32.7° and 44.5°, corresponding to (011), (110), (201) and (112) crystal planes, respectively. The findings are in alignment with prior research, demonstrating the presence of nickel iodide in the catalyst after reaction [9,23]. Compared to the fresh Ni/AC catalysts, the characteristic peaks of Ni species changed or disappeared after reaction. This may be due to active component Ni loss or re-dispersion, resulting in the formation of the new NiI2 and NiI2·6H2O phase [17,35,36]. 3.5 The analysis of Ni loss Ni contents of catalysts were characterized using ICP-OES technique in order to ascertain the extent of Ni loss on the catalyst during the reaction. The fresh catalysts have a Ni content ranging from 10.49-11.14 wt% (Ni/AC-H2O: 10.49%, Ni/AC-HNO3: 11.14%, Ni/AC-2HCl: 10.51%, Ni/AC-6HCl: 10.73%), slightly exceeding the theoretical loading content (10.0 wt%). This occurs due to the breakdown of oxygen-containing groups on support surface throughout the calcination process, which has the effect of reducing the content of the support. After the reaction, the amount of Ni in the catalyst is 7.14% (Ni/AC-H2O), 7.52% (Ni/AC-HNO3), 7.68% (Ni/AC-2HCl) and 9.26% (Ni/AC-6HCl), decreased by 31.9%, 31.4%, 26.9% and 13.7%, respectively. This strongly demonstrates that the chlorine addition can inhibit Ni loss from Ni/AC catalysts during the ethanol carbonylation reaction, thereby improving the stability of the catalysts. As illustrated in Fig. 6 , the lower the Ni loss of the catalyst, the less the catalyst is deactivated, indicating that the primary cause of catalyst deactivation may be Ni loss during ethanol carbonylation process. 3.6 The content of chlorine and Ni state of catalysts The results of the catalytic performance and characterization demonstrate that the incorporation of chlorine has the ability to markedly enhance the stability of the catalysts, through the inhibition of Ni loss and carbon deposition. Consequently, the relative chlorine content on catalyst surface before and after reaction was quantified by SEM-EDS analysis technique, with the results presented in Table 3 . The Ni content on the surface was decreased by 15.7%, 17.7%, 12.6% and 0% for Ni/AC-H2O, Ni/AC-HNO3, Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl after reaction, respectively. This also indicated that the presence of chlorine can inhibit Ni loss from Ni/AC catalysts during the reaction, thus enhancing the stability of the catalysts. No traces of chlorine were found on the surfaces of Ni/AC-H2O and Ni/AC-HNO3. And the chlorine content on the surface decreased by 27.2% and 23.1% for Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl, respectively. This clearly suggested that the content of Ni and Cl on the catalyst surface changed unequally after ethanol carbonylation. Moreover, the relative chlorine content of the catalyst increased with the increase in the amount of HCl adding. Specifically, the chlorine content was 0.11 wt% and 0.13 wt% for Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl before reaction, respectively. The Cl/Ni ratio in Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl before reaction is 0.009 and 0.012, respectively. Therefore, the increase in catalytic stability for the chlorine-containing Ni/AC catalysts is consistent with the higher Cl/Ni ratio. Fig. 7 illustrated the state of Ni of fresh and reduced Ni/AC catalysts. The binding energies of Ni0 and Ni2+ have been identified as 853.0 eV and 855.8 eV, respectively. In addition, the shake-up satellites binding energies of Ni0 and Ni2+ have been determined to be 859.0 eV and 862.0 eV, respectively [37,38]. For the fresh catalysts, the binding energy of the Ni2+ peak in Ni/AC-HNO3 exhibited a slight shift in the direction of greater binding energy (0.26 eV) than that of Ni/AC-H2O. This suggests that an electron transfer from the Ni2+ species to the oxygen groups of the support may have occurred as a result of the HNO3 [17,20]. Furthermore, the Ni 2p3/2 spectra demonstrate a notable shift towards a higher binding energy of 1.71 eV and 1.13 eV in fresh chlorine-containing catalysts, in comparison to the fresh Ni/AC-H2O sample. This indicates the presence of a clear electron transfer from the Ni2+ species to the chlorine-containing AC. After reduction, the signals pertaining to Ni2+ species were still observed, likely due to the unavoidable oxidation of partial Ni0 in air during the XPS experiment. In comparison to the Ni/AC-H2O, the Ni2+ peak binding energy exhibited a slight shift towards higher values, with values of 0.17 eV and 0.19 eV for chlorine-containing catalysts. This is attributable to a decrease in the chlorine content resulting from the reduction of NiCl2 in Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl. However, the observed shift in Ni2+ binding energy indicates that the electrons from Ni2+ are transferred to Cl-, suggesting a stronger interaction between chlorine and Ni than between AC support and Ni. 3.7 H2-TPR analysis In the Ni/AC catalysts without chlorine, two obvious reduction bands are observed, as shown in Fig. 8 H2-TPR curve. The first band, with a maximum around 326-343 °C, can be related to the large NiO particles, which exhibits weak interaction with AC support [39,40]. By comparison, the intensity of this peak is much stronger for Ni/AC-H2O, possibly due to the aggregation of a significant number of large NiO particles on the catalyst. The band located at high temperature approximately 375-400 °C is observed, which could be associate with the reduction of dispersed NiO in close contact with AC [41,42]. However, both Ni/AC-2HCl and Ni/AC-6HCl show another peak at 425 °C, which is assigned to the fact that the chlorine ion residues in the fresh sample primarily bind with Ni2+ ions [43,44]. The data suggest that the interaction between Ni particles and chloride ions is stronger than that of the AC support. And the XPS results were found to be in agreement with the aforementioned findings. 3.8 CO-TPD analysis Both fresh Ni/AC-HNO3 and Ni/AC-H2O have a high CO adsorption capacity, as depicted Fig. 9 a. However, the chlorine-containing catalysts exhibited a significant reduction in CO adsorption capacity, and the CO desorption peak of Ni/AC-2HCl was almost non-existent. Both the Ni dispersion and the pore structure of Ni/AC catalysts have an effect on the adsorption of CO [45]. Nevertheless, no significant changes in N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms or pore structure were observed for fresh Ni/AC catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 2b. Miyao et.al [46] have proved that the presence of chlorine significantly diminished the adsorption intensity of CO and influence the state of Ni. It has been demonstrated that there is no CO desorption in the TPD experiments of Ni/CeO2(Cl) catalysts, which can be attributed to the fact that chlorine may act as a hindrance to CO adsorption [47,48]. Zhuang et al. [49] studied the effect of chlorine on CO adsorption on Ni (110) surface, and pointed out that the strong electronegativity and steric hindrance of chlorine result in a reduction of the charge density of the CO molecule and the bonding of Ni-CO, which in turn leads to a decrease in the averaged dipole moments of the Ni-CO adsorbed complex. Consequently, the adsorption of chlorine on the Ni(110) surface has been observed to significantly reduce the adsorption rate and saturation adsorption capacity of CO. Thus, the chlorine-containing catalysts exhibit significantly lower CO adsorption capacities compared to those without chlorine. This characteristic is not conducive to the activity of ethanol carbonylation reaction. Previous research has demonstrated that the adsorption of CO in the Ni/AC catalyst is a crucial factor in determining the selectivity of ethanol carbonylation [17]. Additionally, there is an accumulation of iodine species on the catalyst surface under ethyl iodide feed, and Ni nanoparticles undergo re-dispersion and form NiI2. Similarly to chlorine, as a consequence, it is conjectured that iodine species also affects the adsorption of CO. The desorption intensity of CO in Ni/AC catalysts without chlorine decreased significantly after reaction, as illustrated in Fig. 9b, indicating that iodine species could restrain the adsorption of CO. However, the CO desorption intensity in Ni/AC catalysts with chlorine are more distinct than those of the non-chlorinated catalysts, suggesting that the presence of chlorine inhibit the adsorption of the compounds containing iodine. This is consistent with the catalyst containing chlorine having less carbon deposits, which are composed of intermediates containing iodine or products. Furthermore, Fig. 9c demonstrates that the catalyst with a higher CO adsorption capacity after the reaction exhibits greater PA and EP selectivity in Ni/AC catalysts. This indicates that the CO adsorption capacity of Ni/AC catalysts during the reactions is of significant importance. 3.9 In-situ DRIFTS study To elucidate the characteristics of surface species during ethanol carbonylation, in-situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted on Ni/AC catalysts, as illustrated in Fig. 10 . Firstly, the investigation began with ethanol and CO being fed to the catalysts in order to ascertain whether chlorine species in chlorine-containing catalysts might play a comparable role to EtI (Fig. 10a and 10b). The adsorption peaks at 2115 and 2170 cm-1 are result from gaseous CO, while the adsorption peaks at 2336 and 2360 cm-1 are indicative of physical adsorption or gaseous CO2 [50,51]. No carbonylation products were observed in Ni/AC-H2O spectra. While ν(C=O) absorption peaks at 1730 and 1760 cm-1 emerged in Ni/AC-6HCl at 22 min of feeding, and these bands disappeared after 30 min of feeding, indicating that carbonylation products were produced on the catalyst, but the reaction ceased shortly thereafter. This phenomenon can be attributed to the interaction between the chlorine presented in Ni/AC-6HCl and Ni. Peng et.al [52] have observed that carbonylation reaction can occur on NiCl2 catalyst when ethanol and CO are co-fed. However, due to the relatively low chlorine content in Ni/AC-6HCl, chlorine will be lost during the carbonylation reaction, resulting in the carbonylation reaction halting. Then co-feeding of CO, ethanol and EtI on Ni/AC-H2O was conducted, as shown in Fig. 10c. As anticipated, the adsorption peak of EtI was observed at 1210 cm-1. The absorption band of carbonylation products was observed at 1760 cm-1 following the 80-min reaction period. Furthermore, the adsorption peak of ν(C=CH) emerged at 950 cm-1 and the adsorption peak of ν(C=O) and ν(O-H) for carboxylic acid at 1714 and 3400 cm-1, respectively [53]. At 220 min, the adsorption peaks of products reached equilibrium. When CO, ethanol and EtI are co-fed on Ni/AC-6HCl in Fig. 10d, the absorption intensity of Ni/AC-6HCl remained stable just at 60 min of reaction time. In comparison to Ni/AC-H2O, the carbonylation reaction on Ni/AC-6HCl reaches a stable state more rapidly, consistent with the catalytic performance in Fig. 1. Moreover, the absorption intensity of ethylene by-products and EtI is significantly lower, again demonstrating chlorine could favor for the reducing the amount of iodine species on Ni/AC catalysts during ethanol carbonylation, in accordance with the result of CO adsorption. Both EtI and CO could be adsorbed on Ni site, and the decreased absorption of EtI on chlorine-containing catalysts is conducive to the CO adsorption, thus stabilize the formation of PA and EP. Moreover, the weaker absorption intensity of ν(C=CH) band for ethylene also demonstrates that the formation of PA and EP in chlorine-containing catalysts is higher, in accordance with the results of catalytic performance. 3.10 The role of chlorine on catalytic performance The catalytic performance indicates that the chlorine addition could effectively improves the catalytic stability. Moreover, the SEM-EDS characterization revealed that the catalyst stability increases with an increase in the chlorine content. By correlation with the structure and performance of the catalysts, the chlorine-containing Ni/AC catalysts can undergo carbonylation reaction without iodide species evidenced by in-situ DRIFTS spectra. This is consistent with the observation that NiCl2-CuCl2 based catalysts for methanol carbonylation can also carbonize in the absence of CH3I [54,55]. Typically, the deactivation of Ni/AC catalysts is due to carbon deposition and Ni loss. N2 physisorption, TG-DSC and Raman spectra indicated that the chlorine could inhibit the carbon deposition to some extent. The delocalized π electrons of AC support interacted with free electrons in C=O, promoting the adsorption of oxygen-containing carbonaceous deposits [20,56]. The chlorine species with strong electrical negativity has a strong ability to absorb electrons, which can inhibit the π electrons of AC support, thus reducing carbon deposition. Nevertheless, the high chlorine content impedes electron transfer between AC support and Ni, resulting in a diminished initial activity of Ni/AC-6HCl in comparison to Ni/AC-H2O. ICP-OES analysis revealed that the primary cause of catalyst deactivation may be Ni loss during ethanol carbonylation. XPS analysis and H2-TPR characterizations further demonstrated that chlorine addition produced a more robust interaction between Ni particles and chloride ions than the interaction between Ni and AC support, which significantly inhibited Ni loss in the catalyst. In-situ DRIFTS analysis revealed that the time required for the reaction to reach a steady state is reduced in Ni/AC-6HCl compared to Ni/AC-H2O. The EtI adsorption on the chlorine-containing catalyst was markedly diminished, which facilitated the adsorption of CO on Ni site during ethanol carbonylation process. Furthermore, the CO-TPD of the post-reaction catalysts substantiates the assertion that the chlorine-containing catalyst exhibits a superior CO adsorption capacity after ethanol carbonylation. Consequently, the selectivity of PA and EP for chlorine-containing catalysts can be maintained at a high level. Additionally, it was observed from in-situ DRIFTS that the intensity of absorption band for ethylene by-products of the chlorine-containing catalyst was lower, which was consistent with the higher selectivity of the catalyst. 4 Conclusion The chlorine-containing Ni/AC catalysts were prepared by adding HCl in order to improve the catalytic stability for heterogeneous ethanol carbonylation. As expected, after 30 h of reaction, the activity loss of Ni/AC-6HCl is found to be 28.8%, which is a significantly lower value than that of Ni/AC-H2O (63.2%). The chlorine-containing catalysts exhibit superior stability compared to Ni/AC-H2O. Moreover, the stability of catalysts increases with an increase in the chlorine content. The primary cause of catalyst deactivation is attributed to Ni loss. In contrast to the interaction between AC support and Ni, there is a more pronounced interaction between Ni and chlorine in chlorine-containing catalysts, which serves to inhibit Ni loss. The loss of Ni content decreased from 31.9% of Ni/AC-H2O to 13.7% of Ni/AC-6HCl. Furthermore, chlorine inhibits the delocalized π electrons of the AC, thus reducing the amount of deposited carbonaceous species containing iodine in the catalyst. In-situ DRIFTS and CO-TPD state clearly that chlorine addition weakens the adsorption of iodine species during the reaction, thus improve the adsorption capacity of CO on Ni site. Therefore, the chlorine-containing catalysts can be maintained at a high-level product selectivity during ethanol carbonylation. Nevertheless, the catalyst with chlorine containing remains deactivated, possibly due to the loss of chlorine as the reaction progresses. Consequently, it would be beneficial in future studies to consider stabilizing chlorine in the catalyst or adjusting the amount of EtI, in order to further improve the stability of the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The heterogeneous ethanol carbonylation of Ni supported on activated carbon (Ni/AC) is typically associated with significant activity loss, largely due to the facile occurrence of carbon deposition and Ni loss. In this study, the chlorine-containing Ni/AC catalysts were synthesized via the incipient wetness method and exhibited superior stability compared to catalysts without chlorine. Correlation of the catalytic performance and catalyst structure revealed that chlorine addition to Ni/AC reduced the amount of carbon deposition. Moreover, it is evident that there is a robust interaction between chlorine and Ni, as evidenced by XPS and H2-TPR, which can significantly impede the Ni loss during the reaction. The results of in-situ DRIFTS and CO-TPD experiments demonstrate that the addition of chlorine impedes the adsorption of iodine species on Ni/AC catalysts, which consequently affects the adsorption capacity of CO closely associated with the product selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Chlorine-containing Ni/AC catalysts for heterogeneous ethanol carbonylation
